Appendix 1:Preliminary Equality Analysis Appendix 2: Equality Impact Assessment Form Appendix 3: Feeding at Risk Consent Form Appendix 4: Feeding at Risk Decision Plan Appendix 5 Feeding at Risk Questionnaire Appendix 6: Feeding at Risk – GP Letter Appendix 7: Dementia care Pathway 2018

This document will guide healthcare professionals through the decision making process when people have been identified to be feeding at risk. It encompasses patient choice, involving carers and ensuring clear documentation of the decision reached.

It also addresses capacity, ethics and quality of life issues, providing the Multi-Disciplinary team (MDT) with a patient centred framework to facilitate decision making regarding nutritional management.

The feeding at risk process ensures that all aspects of care and potential outcomes are considered. This approach should result in a patient centred decision which is made with serious thought and over a reasonable time frame. This approach is suitable for patients with life-limiting conditions where their prognosis is less than a year and/or swallowing or feeding is an issue, e.g. COPD, multiple complex diagnoses and Dementia.
This policy covers the ‘feeding at risk' process throughout the pathway from admission to discharge and is essential to ensure consistent transfer of care between acute and community settings.

Nutrition forms the key priority for many healthcare organisations and providing oral intake of food/drink is often an important issue for carers. Managing the risks of oral intake for patients with eating and swallowing problems is important in terms of safety, but can be a challenging ethical dilemma for healthcare professionals and carers.

Some patients will fail to manage the food bolus adequately once it is in the mouth (oral phased dysphagia) or aspirate when swallowing (pharyngeal phase dysphagia) and are at risk of choking and aspiration. Other patients can lose interest in food at the end stage of life and those with end stage dementia may lose the ability to recognise food.

The challenge arises when these patients are deemed unsuitable for artificial nutrition or hydration (ANH) following a multidiscilplinary team (MDT) discussion usually involving the medical team, the dietician and the speech and language therapist (SALT).

A patient may be an inappropriate candidate for ANH if the risk of procedure outweighs the benefit; the patient themselves decline ANH or there is poor prognosis/a short life expectency. Clinicians are then faced with the dilemma of how best to manage these patients who are unsuitable for ANH but at risk of choking on food/fluid and developing an aspiration pneumonia.

The descision making process regarding whether to introduce artificial nutrition and hydration or continue to allow food and drink orally once their swallowing becomes unsafe, provokes difficult ethical and medical decisions for professional, patients and carers.

Professionals need to work together to ensure the risks and benefits of eating and drinking are considered for each individual person to optimise their quality of life. This co-ordinated approach, particularly towards the end of life, is essential for patients with chronic progressive conditions, to ensure consistent and smooth transfer of care between acute and community settings.

Feeding at risk is the continutation of careful oral feeding when ANH is not appropriate. It acknowledges that there are risks of aspiration and aims to minimise these risks as much as possible. It is likely that when a person is feeding at risk, they will not meet their nutrition and hydration needs. Often feeding at risk is to enhance quality of life and maintain the comfort and pleasure that comes from eating and drinking. It is generally accepted that these patients are or will be in the palliative stage of their care. Palliative care is defined as the active holistic care of patients with advanced illness. The goal of palliative care is to achieve the best quality of life for patients and their families.
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 1)

This policy relates to all adults admitted to all wards who have, following an assessment by an SALT, been identified as being unsafe to eat and drinkdue to a chronic medical condition e.g. frailty, dementia, COPD and there are concerns about their oral intake due to swallowing difficulties

Feeding at risk would be considered where there is not a transient or reversible cause for dysphagia e.g. infection, vascular event or the patient is non-compliant with recommendations to manage the swallowing difficulty.
Feeding at risk should be considered in the following situations:
A patient is deemed unsafe to eat and drink and is found to be unsuitable for artificial nutrition or hydration (ANH).
A patient has mental capacity, understands fully the high risks of aspiration from oral intake but chooses to continue to eat and drink consistencies which present a greater risk of aspiration.

table_items.text: Giving an individual nutrition and fluids by another means instead of by mouth
Where food or drink passes below the vocal folds and enters the lungs
An infection in the lungs caused by food, fluid, saliva containing bacteria, or vomit entering the lungs
A process of discussion between an individual and their care providers to make clear a person's wishes, often in the context of anticipated deterioration
The substance that is being swallowed e.g mouthful of food or drink.
The ability to make a specific decision at a specific time. This should be assessed in line with the Mental capacity Act Code of Practice-adhering to its key principles
Where the individual is fed by the care giver or given hand over hand support to eat and drink. A skilled approach which recognises the vulnerability of dependent individuals.

Finucane TE,et al.Tube feeding in patients with advanced dementia: a review of the evidence. J AmMedicalAssociation 1999; 282:14,1365-1370 Palecek E J, et al. Comfort feeding only J Am Geriatric Society MAR 2010;58(3):580- 584.
Where behaviours associated with deteriorating cognition or mental function impact on eating and drinking
Royal College of Physcians (2010) Oral feeding difficulties and dilemas RCP London
Feeding at Risk Risk feeding Comfort feeding Palliative Feeding Risk
Where an individual continues to eat and drink in spite of the risk of food and fluid entering the lungs

data.text: Responsibilities
Consultant  To make the ultimate decision once the patient has been clinically discussed with the MDT and options shared with the family
Doctor  To initiate the dialogue regarding feeding at risk management and commence a mental capacity assessment
To refer to SALT for swallowing assessment
To  include  feeding  at  risk  guidelines  in  the  discharge
summary
To ensure that anticipatory health care plans are completed
when needed
To ensure patient and family are updated regularly on the
decision making process
Speech &  To conduct a detailed assessment of swallow
Language Therapist  To  conduct or facilitate  a  mental  capacity  assessment  if
needed
To discuss findings of the assessment with the MDT
To manage safest volumes, dietary textures and need for thickened fluids.
To  consider  risks  of  malnutrition,  dehydration,  medication management, patient choice, in the decision.
To  report/communicate  recommendations  to  relevant professionals e.g. Physiotherapist, GP

Dietitian  To aid in the evaluation/candidacy of a patient for artificial nutrition. To evaluate the degree of nutrional deficit as this may be useful  in  decision  making  regarding  prognosis  where appropriate.
Physiotherapist  To discuss respiratory management with the medical team and ceiling of care with respiratory needs
Nurses  To  refer  to  the  medical  team/SALT  if  a  patient  is  having swallowing difficulties
To ensure risk reducing recommendations are being adhered to
To facilitate timely discussion and support decisions that are individualised,  patient  centred  with  the  patient's  best interests.
To act as the patient advocate as necessary as part of the MDT, keep the patient and family informed.
To ensure the correct meal is provided for the patient under the guidance from the SLT who has assessed the patient and advised on the safest consistency the patient can manage.
Palliative Care  To inform the MDT if the patient has been placed on the end of life pathway
Training will be provided through multiple channels, including the Nutrition strategy group (NSG), Dementia and Delirium steering groups, senior nurse meetings, and the Trust education programme

The Mental Capacity Act (MCA)  provides a statutory framework for people who lack the mental capacity to make decisions for themselves in connection with their care or treatment and stipulates how decisions should be formulated where a patient is deemed to lack mental capacity for this specific capacity
If there is suggestion that the person may lack mental capacity to make decisions around risk feeding, a full mental capacity assessment must be carried out.

The layout of the Feeding at risk Decision Plan ensures that, if completed in full, mental capacity assessments have been undertaken in accordance with the following MEHT Mental Capacity Act (2005) Policy 11001
The Mental Capacity Assessment is available on the Trust Intranet site under the Adult Safeguarding page.
The following websites will provide you with more information on the Mental Capacity Act.
www.direct.gov.uk

data.url: 19001 Feeding at Risk Operational Guidance for Adults 1.1.003.png

data.text: Appropriate nursing handover should take place to ensure that the risk is acknowledged and minimised with scrupulous oral care and optimum seating position and that, where required, careful hand feeding is offered. In an acute setting it is also essential to inform the relevent physiopherapist so that chest intervention for that patient can be discussed with the medical team. It is also expected that SALT will monitor the patient on a weekly basis until discharge.

For patients who are nearing the end of life and where a decision has been made for feeding at risk, the responsible medical team should consider what treatment escalation should occur in the event of a deterioration in the patients condition. For patients who lack mental capacity (11001 Mental capacity Act (2005) Policy) for the relevent decisions, the MCA must be adhered to and any resulting anticipatory treatment plan is advisory only, with each best interest decision being made at the time it is needed. This plan must be documented in the notes and in the advance treatment plan. Any anticipatory care plan must be communicated to the patients GP.

For patients assessed to be in their final hours or days of life, A palliative individualised plan of care should be developed to include safe oral hydration and nutrition. Offer food and fluids as tolerated along with symptom control, psychological, social and spiritual support for the patient and family

The SALT needs to work closely with the medical team members in ensuring that feeding at risk is appropriately reflected in the discharge summaries or advanced health care plans. This should include whether or not to readmit the patient for acute hospital treatment should they be diagnosed with aspiration pneumonia by the GP. This forms a crucial stage in the process allowing the patient to leave the acute setting with a clear plan in place informing future management. A letter should be sent out to the GP with guidance and information leaflets sent to the home/nursing home. (Refer to Appendix 4)

It is good practice to make a referral to the community SALT team for every patient with a feeding at risk plan in place. Respective community teams may develop their own policy around offering further support and guidance or discharge after the initial contact. This duty of care enables the patient and those around them to be supported in their own environment. This allows cohesive care of community patients and in collaboration with the GP practices can support the patient who is being risk fed to be managed at home. These steps are vital to avoiding aspiration related readmissions within this client group.
All incidents should be reported on Datix in line with the Trust Incident Reporting Policy.

A Datix must also be completed if there is any evidence that the patient has come to emotional or physical harm in hospital or if there is evidence that the patient has been administered incorrect diet textures or fluids
The aim of a post incident review should seek to learn lessons, support staff and the patient and encourage a relationship between staff, patient and relatives or carers.
The review should be conducted as soon as possible after the incident and by someone independent of the incident.
Clinician's should refer to the Clinical Decision Plan in Appendix 2
It is essential that initiation of the Feeding at Risk plan is preceded by detailed information gathering to establish:
The nature of the patient's dysphagia;
The patient's diagnosis;
The patient's prognosis;
The patients normal eating and drinking regime;
Whether the patient's clinical presentation is transient and reversible in nature or unlikely to improve even with treatment;
How future management will reduce a patient's distress and improve their comfort and dignity.

If the patient's dysphagia is transient and has a reversible cause, a time limited trial of tube feeding (usually nasogastric feeding) maybe appropriate. A trial will have clear, agreed objectives and time scales with regular reviews to assess the benefits. The proposed feeding tube removal date should be documented in the medical records.

If the patient has a diagnosis of Dementia please follow the flowchart for people with dementia who are not eating and drinking adequately prior to the decision regarding feeding at risk (see Appendix 5)
If there is no reversible or transient cause to the dysphagia then all staff must follow the Feeding at Risk Clinical Decision Plan (see Appendix 2)
Determine whether patient has mental capacity;
Commence full MDT assessment;
Conduct appropriate discussions;
Complete Feeding at Risk Document (Appendix 2);
Initiate Feeding at Risk Plan;
Commence SALT recommendations for safe oral feeding or follow emergency oral feeding plan (Appendix 2 Step 3A) if awaiting SALT assessments/recommendations;
Communicate decision and feeding plan across all relevant healthcare settings.

The effectiveness of the guideline will be monitored by annual review of randomly selected case notes of patients identified as needing to be feeding at risk to assess compliance with the guideline. This will take place by the Adult Speech and Language Therapy team.
The guideline will be made available on the Trust's intranet & website by Governance.
The approved guideline will be notified in the Trust's Staff Focus.

Chaklader E (2012). Dysphagia management for older people towards the end of life. British Geriatric Society. Http://www.bgs.org.uk/index.php/topresources/publicationfind/goodpractice/23 28-bpgdysphagia
Evans L Best C (2025). Managing malnutrition in patients with Dementia. Nursing Standard. Vol 29 No 28 pp 50-57
General Medical Council (2010) Treatment and care towards the end of life: Good practice in decision making.
http:// www.gmc-uk.org/static /documents/content/Treatment and care towards the end of life-English 1015. Pdf #
Hansjee D (2013. A safer approach to risk feeding. Bulletin ww.rcSALT.org.uk, February 2013 pp 20 -21
Harwood R.H. (2014) Feeding decisions in advanced dementia. Journal of the Royal College of physicians, Edinburgh, 44, 232-237
Leadership Alliance for the care of the dying People (2014). One chance to get  it  right. http://www.gov/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachmentdata/file32318 8/Onechance to get it right.pdf
Mcginley E (2015) Role of Nutrition in the final stages of palliative care Journal of community nursing, Vol 29 No 1 – pp 53-58
Mental Capacity Act (2005) https:/www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachmentdata file/224660/Mental Capacity act code of practice.pdf

National Institute for Health and clinical Excellence (2004). Improving supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer. Cancer service guideline CSG4. Reviewed with no amendments, June  https:/ www.nice.org/guidance csg4
National Institute for Health & Clinical Excellence (2015) Care of the Dying Adults in the Last Days of Life (NG31)

Royal College of Phycians (2010). Oral feeding difficulties and dilemmas: A guide to practical care, particularly towards the end of life. Report of a working party, Royal College of Physicians. www.rcplondon.ac.uk
Clinically Assisted Nutrition and Hydration Guidance (CANH) BMA 2018 www.bma.org.uk/advice/employment/ethics/mentalcapacity/clinically assisted.
